1: Draw beautiful digital electronics timing diagrams in LaTeX - 2014 10 29

2: Today, for one of my engineering courses, I had to create some timing diagrams to show certain
3: parts of the PCI standard. If you’ve never had to draw your own timing diagrams before, then you

0: Today, for one of my engineering courses, I had to create some timing diagrams to show certain
1: parts of the PCI standard. If you’ve never had to draw your own timing diagrams before, then you
2: probably haven’t realized that there is no obvious to quickly, easily draw waveforms for a bunch
4: The solution I found is tikz-timing . An alternative is timing.sty , which is simple and pretty
6: I find the more advanced features of tikz-timing invaluable for versatility, though—there’s
7: nothing like needing to talk about a signal transition in some text, and, oh yeah, just drawing
9: The only problem with tikz-timing is a shortage of examples. The package documentation has but a
10: handful, and they don’t look much like real-world timing diagrams. The texample.net timing
11: diagrams are just copied directly from that manual, which isn’t useful. So I figure I’ll post
13: To get started, I included the package like this:
14: Then I defined a command so I could reference a bus: 1
15: The PCI timing diagrams are drawn with reference to version 2.2 of the PCI specification. I
16: added the DEVSEL# signal myself, 2 and I’ve taken some slight liberties with the start and stop
17: times of the signals (though they should still be accurate). One notable feature lacking in my
18: diagrams is the delay cycles—most books you’ll read on PCI, in addition to the spec itself will
19: include those directly on the diagram. I haven’t figured out how to do that kind of thing yet.
20: You can think of the tikztimingtable environment as two-column tables with some special syntax
21: for the righthand column. The gist of it is this: there are signal variants, and you create them
22: by writing a letter that serves as a key. Each key has two variants: a half-duration lowercase
23: one and a full-duration uppercase one.
24: So to make the clock signal in the PCI read diagram, it’s 18 half-duration clock cycles, and we
25: write that 18{c} . The brackets there aren’t strictly necessary, but you can write them for
26: clarity. Signal changes are separated by spaces if there’s any ambiguity about what argument
28: In the above example, I used these letters to make the signals:

2: I was going through my ODE notes the other day and wondered if I could solve any of them with

0: I was going through my ODE notes the other day and wondered if I could solve any of them with
1: Python. I gave it a shot for one of the simpler equations, and here are my results (with
5: where \(y\) is a function of \(t\) and the initial values \(y(0) = 1\) , \(y'(0)=0\) . Can we
6: write an equation for \(y\) , or at least get some answers about its behavior?
7: In real life, this sort of problem often comes up when you’re dealing with a circuit containing
8: a capacitor that discharges through an inductor over time, and you want to analyze the voltage
9: or current going through any given part of the circuit while this happens. Generally speaking,
10: this is only one small part of a real-life circuit problem: you know that when you flip some
11: switch, the circuit can be simplified to the above equation and that lets you solve it for some
12: range \(t_1 < t < t_2\) , where \(t_1\) and \(t_2\) are the time boundaries where you didn’t
14: Our analytic solution will let us write an equation for \(y\) that’s solvable for any time \(t\)
15: , but the numeric solution in Python will just give us answers in some range that we actually
16: calculate. Depending on what we’re trying to do with the answer, the numeric solution might be
18: If you’ve taken a class on ordinary differential equations, then you should recognize this as a
19: second-order linear homogeneous ODE with constant coefficients. If you haven’t, no big deal then
20: either. Regardless, I’ll go over the exact analytical answer, since it’s pretty easy to find in
22: An equation of the form \[ \alpha y''+\beta y'+ \gamma y=0, \] where \(\alpha\) , \(\beta\) ,
23: \(\gamma\) are some constants, has a characteristic equation \[\alpha r^2 + \beta r +
24: \gamma=0.\] Once we have this characteristic equation we can avoid actually doing any calculus
25: and just solving that quadratic. So our characteristic equation here is \[r^2+r+2=0\] and its
26: roots \(r_{1,2}\) are \[r_{1,2} = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{-7}}{2},\] found using the quadratic
27: equation \[x=\frac{-b\pm \sqrt{b^2 -4ac}}{2a}.\] Noting that \(r_{1,2}\) are both complex, the
28: general form for our solution here is thus 1 \[y=e^{\alpha t}(c_1 \cos{\beta t} + c_2 \sin{\beta

2: I haven’t blogged in a few months. I’ve tried to write a number of times, and even sat down and
3: thought I had a good idea and could write a blog post about it. Then I’d hammer out a few
4: paragraphs, decide they’re stupid, and end up not pushing them out to my webserver out of fear
5: that people would think I seem dumb.
6: This process wasn’t overt; it happened under the hood, and I kept diguising in my head and
7: telling myself it was just writer’s block. Then I read Josh Davis’ post about putting yourself
8: out there, and what I’ve been feeling was clear as day: I’ve just been isolating myself, and
9: it’s a totally separate process from having writer’s block or not having ideas.

0: I haven’t blogged in a few months. I’ve tried to write a number of times, and even sat down and
1: thought I had a good idea and could write a blog post about it. Then I’d hammer out a few
2: paragraphs, decide they’re stupid, and end up not pushing them out to my webserver out of fear
3: that people would think I seem dumb.
4: This process wasn’t overt; it happened under the hood, and I kept diguising in my head and
5: telling myself it was just writer’s block. Then I read Josh Davis’ post about putting yourself
6: out there, and what I’ve been feeling was clear as day: I’ve just been isolating myself, and
7: it’s a totally separate process from having writer’s block or not having ideas.
8: In his blog post, Josh summarizes a Google I/O talk titled The Myth of the Genius Programmer .
9: He boils it down to four core points:
10: It occurs to me that this applies to more than just software. Nobody has ever achieved anything
11: meaningful by not making themselves vulnerable. If you want to start a company, or write a
12: novel, or just get in a habit of going to the gym every day, you need to make yourself
14: I can’t be the only one who has made excuses to myself like:
15: The problem with these excuses is twofold:
16: In each of these examples, it looks like the problem is actually something obvious: you’re not
17: feeling creative, or you’re busy, or you’re not experienced enough. These are all temporary
18: obstructions, things you can overcome now that you recognize them. They’re all things that might
19: go away with time, or with a bit of practice, or an ease on you workload. But if the real
20: problem is just that you’re not making yourself vulnerable, then you don’t naturally make that
21: leap from the reason you think you’re not succeeding to why you’re actually failing.
22: But second, and just as insidiously, you’re deceived into believing that whatever you’re doing
23: instead of getting out there is a good use of your time. This is almost never the case.
24: Programmers don’t write good code by crawling into a cave and pecking away - they communicate,
25: they interact with others, and they take criticism and turn it around into useful changes.
26: The pair of these two is something I’ll call the genius anti-loop . 1 It goes like this:
27: I read a blog post a while back that was somewhat similar to this. 2 Except it argued that even
28: though there are genius programmers out there, we shouldn’t try to be like them. We should be

2: I made the move from Arch Linux to Debian last week. Someone on the CNULUG mailing list asked me
3: about it and I provided the following explanation:
4: No official support for alternate initsystems (Debian at least has open debate about OpenRC vs
6: [Arch has a r]elatively closed development cycle compared to Debian. It’s hard to follow what
7: the devs are doing, even tracking arch-dev-public and the archlinux mailing list isn’t on par
9: [Debian’s] wider array of packages mean I have to deal with less of the awful quality of AUR
10: PKGBUILDs. There’s no time spent messing around trying to get it to work because the developer
11: hasn’t updated it in forever. Likewise, there’s no questioning whether or not I can trust the
12: author of the PKGBUILD to be both (a) smart and (b) in my best interest (in terms of security).
13: The debian packages hit a huge number of users, and there is active debate about each and every
14: one of them in the mailing list - the same of which I wouldn’t say for the AUR.

0: I made the move from Arch Linux to Debian last week. Someone on the CNULUG mailing list asked me
1: about it and I provided the following explanation:
2: No official support for alternate initsystems (Debian at least has open debate about OpenRC vs
4: [Arch has a r]elatively closed development cycle compared to Debian. It’s hard to follow what
5: the devs are doing, even tracking arch-dev-public and the archlinux mailing list isn’t on par
7: [Debian’s] wider array of packages mean I have to deal with less of the awful quality of AUR
8: PKGBUILDs. There’s no time spent messing around trying to get it to work because the developer
9: hasn’t updated it in forever. Likewise, there’s no questioning whether or not I can trust the
10: author of the PKGBUILD to be both (a) smart and (b) in my best interest (in terms of security).
11: The debian packages hit a huge number of users, and there is active debate about each and every
12: one of them in the mailing list - the same of which I wouldn’t say for the AUR.
13: Desire to deviate from upstream. Arch locks their packages to upstream, even if it doens’t make
14: the most sense. Examples include naming the GPG keys produced by mutt. On Arch, they use vanilla
15: mutt so you don’t get the patch that lets your GPG keys be named (e.g. in Gmail) signature.asc
16: instead of noname . This is one little thing, but there are a number of packages I have to patch
17: and update myself on Arch where on every other distribution there is a set of commonly used
18: patches the developers just expect you to want. This is especially true of legacy applications
19: like mutt.
20: So far, the switch has been OK, but far from painless. There are numerous little details that
21: you take for granted when you’re running Arch, like the simplicity of the package manager. On
22: Arch, your package management configuration goes in /etc/pacman.conf . The lines I am concerned
23: with look like the following:
24: Breaking this down, # means a commented line, and the [core] , etc. headings represent
25: individual repositories. The order that the repositories are listed signifies their precedence.
26: The Include = line points to the file with the list of mirrors for the repo. If you want to
27: ignore a certain package from updates, there is an IgnorePkg= line that you change, to signify
28: that you want to ignore it.

1: All your daemons are belong to us - 2014  7 25

2: This January I switched from Arch to Debian , and I was very happy with it. Now I’m back on

0: This January I switched from Arch to Debian , and I was very happy with it. Now I’m back on
2: After using it for six months, I love Debian. I finally understand what it’s like to have a
3: user-friendly operating system that is still powerful for the experts. But the problems I had
4: with it were hit just as I started transitioning toward expert usage: on Debian, doing the
5: advanced things is harder than doing them on Arch.
6: So I’ve gone back. And I love Arch just as much as ever, and appreciate it a bit more now that
8: Even though it was something I complained about in Arch, the one big thing I ended up missing
9: was systemd. Arch makes systemd a first-class citizen. Debian has been in the middle of an
10: official switch for months, but it still feels painful and not fully thought out. In retrospect,
11: this makes sense: Arch has been on systemd for years , and Debian only announced systemd as the
12: official init system back in February .
13: Of course, Debian has systemd. Jessie had the 204 release for most of the time I was using it.
14: I’m back on Arch now, running systemd 215. As someone who uses my computer as a laptop and not,
15: you know, a server, systemd user sessions are among the most useful features it has to offer.
16: Not long ago, I posted a horrible script for daemonizing my personal wiki. It barely worked.
17: Sometimes it would cause ps to bug and report problems, which I was told to submit to the
18: developers. Unfortunately, the line reported for causing the bug was the same line that was
19: supposed to display information about the bug. I also have no idea where I’m supposed to report
20: the bug - here at SourceForge ? Who knows.
21: In lieu of writing a better script, something that uses mkdir for PID locks, 1 I started to miss
22: the sheer beauty of letting systemd manage my user-level init. To me, it’s a simple fact that
23: using shell scripts to spawn daemons for, say X startup is archaic, awful, and prone to errors.
24: On Arch, I can do this:
25: and it spawns my wiki process, keeps logs, and monitors its status like any other daemon. I’ve
26: aliased userctl to systemctl --user , since it’s way easier to type and makes more sense in my
28: The script, located at $HOME/.config/systemd/user/gitit.service , looks like so:
